data.question: What are the main interactions responsible for the binding of CO2 and SO2 molecules within NOTT-300?
data.answer: Hydrogen bonds formed between the gases and the hydroxyl groups within the pore channels, supplemented by weaker supramolecular interactions with C–H groups on the aromatic rings of the framework

data.question: How does the isosteric heat of adsorption for CO2 in NOTT-300 compare to amine-functionalized materials?
data.answer: The isosteric heat of adsorption in NOTT-300 (27–30 kJ mol-1) is lower than in amine-functionalized materials (40–90 kJ mol-1 for physisorption; 85–105 kJ mol-1 for chemisorption)

data.question: What technique was employed to determine the preferred binding sites for SO2 molecules within NOTT-300?

data.question: What is the significance of the moderate to weak hydrogen bonds in NOTT-300 for CO2 and SO2 capture?
data.answer: These moderate to weak hydrogen bonds are sufficiently strong to selectively bind CO2 and SO2, yet allow for their facile, low-energy release, making NOTT-300 an efficient and economically viable material for gas capture

What is the role of the cis configuration of m2-OH groups in NOTT-300?
data.answer: The cis configuration of m2-OH groups is responsible for the chirality and rigidity of the framework in NOTT-300, forming square-shaped channels with hydroxyl groups protruding into them
